Fork this repository to your account. Enable the Issues tab: Go to the Settings tab and check the Issues option. Add your professor as a collaborator: Go to the Settings tab and add their GitHub username in the Collaborators section. docs.text: Problem 2 – Friction on Inclined Plane Problem Statement A 5 kg block is placed on a 30° inclined plane. The coefficient of kinetic friction is 0.2. Calculate the net force acting on the block as it slides down. Given: Mass \( m = 5 \, \text{kg} \) Incline angle \( \theta = 30^\circ \) Coefficient of kinetic friction \( \mu_k = 0.2 \) Formulas: Gravitational force component: \( F_g = m \cdot g \cdot \sin(\theta) \) Normal force: \( N = m \cdot g \cdot \cos(\theta) \) Friction force: \( f_k = \mu_k \cdot N \) Net force: \( F_{net} = F_g - f_k \) Calculation: \[ \begin{align*} F_g &= 5 \cdot 9.8 \cdot \sin(30^\circ) = 24.5 \, \text{N} \\ N &= 5 \cdot 9.8 \cdot \cos(30^\circ) \approx 42.44 \, \text{N} \\ f_k &= 0.2 \cdot 42.44 \approx 8.49 \, \text{N} \\ F_{net} &= 24.5 - 8.49 = 16.01 \, \text{N} \end{align*} \] Final Answer: The net force acting on the block is approximately 16.01 N down the incline.
docs.title: Problem 2 – Friction on Inclined Plane

docs.text: Problem 3 – Motion Under Gravity Problem Statement A ball is thrown vertically upward with an initial velocity of 20 m/s. Calculate the maximum height it reaches and the total time it takes to return to the ground. Assumptions No air resistance Gravity is constant: \( g = 9.8 \, \text{m/s}^2 \) Formulas Maximum height: \( h = \frac{v_0^2}{2g} \) Time to reach max height: \( t = \frac{v_0}{g} \) Total time: \( T = 2t \) Solution \[ h = \frac{20^2}{2 \cdot 9.8} = \frac{400}{19.6} \approx 20.41 \, \text{m} \] \[ t = \frac{20}{9.8} \approx 2.04 \, \text{s} \Rightarrow T = 4.08 \, \text{s} \] Result Maximum height: 20.41 m Total time of flight: 4.08 s Visualization
docs.title: Problem 3 – Motion Under Gravity

docs.text: Problem 4 – Electromagnetic Induction Problem Statement A circular loop of radius 0.1 m is placed in a uniform magnetic field perpendicular to its plane. The magnetic field changes uniformly from 0.5 T to 0 T in 2 seconds. Calculate the induced EMF in the loop. Given: Radius \( r = 0.1 \, \text{m} \) Initial magnetic field \( B_i = 0.5 \, \text{T} \) Final magnetic field \( B_f = 0 \, \text{T} \) Time interval \( \Delta t = 2 \, \text{s} \) Formula: Faraday’s Law of Induction: \[ \mathcal{E} = -\frac{d\Phi_B}{dt} = -\frac{A \cdot (B_f - B_i)}{\Delta t} \] Where: \( \mathcal{E} \) is the induced EMF \( A = \pi r^2 \) is the area of the loop Calculation: \[ A = \pi (0.1)^2 = 0.0314 \, \text{m}^2 \\ \mathcal{E} = -\frac{0.0314 \cdot (0 - 0.5)}{2} = 0.00785 \, \text{V} \] Final Answer: The induced EMF in the loop is approximately 0.00785 volts .
docs.title: Problem 4 – Electromagnetic Induction

docs.text: Problem 1 – Electromagnetic Induction Problem Statement A 5-turn circular coil of radius 0.1 m is placed in a uniform magnetic field perpendicular to its plane. The magnetic field increases from 0.1 T to 0.5 T in 2 seconds. Calculate the average induced emf in the coil. Given: Number of turns: \( N = 5 \) Radius: \( r = 0.1 \, \text{m} \) Initial magnetic field: \( B_i = 0.1 \, \text{T} \) Final magnetic field: \( B_f = 0.5 \, \text{T} \) Time: \( \Delta t = 2 \, \text{s} \) Formula: Faraday’s Law of Electromagnetic Induction: \[ \mathcal{E} = -N \cdot \frac{\Delta \Phi}{\Delta t} \quad \text{where} \quad \Phi = B \cdot A \] Area of circular coil: \[ A = \pi r^2 \] Calculation: \[ A = \pi (0.1)^2 = 0.0314 \, \text{m}^2 \] \[ \Delta \Phi = B_f \cdot A - B_i \cdot A = (0.5 - 0.1) \cdot 0.0314 = 0.01256 \, \text{Wb} \] \[ \mathcal{E} = -5 \cdot \frac{0.01256}{2} = -0.0314 \, \text{V} \] Final Answer: The average induced emf in the coil is 0.0314 V (magnitude). Visualization Below is a graph showing the induced emf over time assuming constant speed and uniform field.
docs.title: Problem 1 – Electromagnetic Induction

docs.title: Given:

docs.text: Faraday’s Law of Electromagnetic Induction: \[ \mathcal{E} = -N \cdot \frac{\Delta \Phi}{\Delta t} \quad \text{where} \quad \Phi = B \cdot A \] Area of circular coil: \[ A = \pi r^2 \]
docs.title: Formula:

docs.text: The average induced emf in the coil is 0.0314 V (magnitude).
docs.title: Final Answer:

docs.text: Problem 5 – Kirchhoff’s Laws Problem Statement A simple circuit has two resistors: R₁ = 2 Ω and R₂ = 3 Ω, and a battery of V = 12 V. Using Kirchhoff’s laws, calculate the current through each resistor and the voltage drop. Given: R₁ = 2 Ω R₂ = 3 Ω V = 12 V Formulas: Ohm’s Law: V = I × R Kirchhoff’s Voltage Law (KVL): Sum of voltage drops = Battery voltage Calculation: Let I₁ = current through R₁ Let I₂ = current through R₂ Total Resistance, R_total = R₁ + R₂ = 2 + 3 = 5 Ω Total Current, I = V / R_total = 12 / 5 = 2.4 A Voltage drop across R₁ = I × R₁ = 2.4 × 2 = 4.8 V Voltage drop across R₂ = I × R₂ = 2.4 × 3 = 7.2 V Visualization Below is a graph showing the voltage drops across each resistor in the series:
docs.title: Problem 5 – Kirchhoff’s Laws

docs.text: Problem 6 – Descriptive Statistics Problem Statement Given a dataset of five measurements: 4, 7, 6, 5, 8 — calculate the mean , median , and mode . Given: Dataset: 4, 7, 6, 5, 8 Formulas: Mean: \( \bar{x} = \frac{\sum x_i}{n} \) Median: Middle value in ordered data Mode: Most frequent value Calculation: \[ \text{Mean} = \frac{4 + 7 + 6 + 5 + 8}{5} = \frac{30}{5} = 6 \\ \text{Ordered data} = 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 \Rightarrow \text{Median} = 6 \\ \text{Each number occurs once} \Rightarrow \text{Mode} = \text{None} \] Visualization Below is a visualization of the dataset distribution:
docs.title: Problem 6 – Descriptive Statistics

docs.text: Problem 7 – Probability Basics Problem Statement A die is rolled once. What is the probability of getting a number greater than 4? Given: Sample Space: {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} Favorable Outcomes: {5, 6} Formula: \[ P(E) = \frac{\text{Number of favorable outcomes}}{\text{Total number of outcomes}} \] Calculation: \[ P(\text{greater than 4}) = \frac{2}{6} = \frac{1}{3} \] Visualization Below is a bar graph showing the theoretical probability distribution of a fair die:
docs.title: Problem 7 – Probability Basics

docs.text: Problem 8 – Uncertainty in Measurements Problem Statement A student measures the length of a rod three times: 20.2 cm, 20.5 cm, and 20.3 cm. Calculate the average length and the uncertainty of the measurements. Given: Measurements: 20.2 cm, 20.5 cm, 20.3 cm Formulas: Average: \( \bar{x} = \frac{x_1 + x_2 + x_3}{3} \) Uncertainty: \( \Delta x = \frac{\text{max value} - \text{min value}}{2} \) Calculation: Average: [ \bar{x} = \frac{20.2 + 20.5 + 20.3}{3} = \frac{61.0}{3} = 20.33 \, \text{cm} ] Uncertainty: [ \Delta x = \frac{20.5 - 20.2}{2} = \frac{0.3}{2} = 0.15 \, \text{cm} ] Visualization Below is a graphical representation of the measurements:
docs.title: Problem 8 – Uncertainty in Measurements
